case_vignette:
A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum for the past 10 days. During this time, he had three episodes of blood in his urine. Six years ago, he was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis after a positive routine tuberculin skin test, and he was treated accordingly. His maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient does not take any medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard at both lung bases. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Urea nitrogen 32 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.5 mg/dL
Urine
Protein 2+
Blood 3+
RBC casts numerous
WBC casts negative
A chest x-ray shows patchy, pulmonary infiltrates bilaterally. A renal biopsy in this patient shows linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?" (Source: http://www.doctorlib.org/medical-questions/renal-biopsy-findings-linear-deposits-of-igg-along-the-glomerular-basement-membrane.html)

## Step 1: Identify the gender-specific references in the text.
The text contains the following gender-specific references: "24-year-old man", "maternal aunt", and the pronouns "he" and "his".

## Step 2: Swap the gender-specific references.
To swap the gender-specific references, we need to replace "man" with "woman", "maternal aunt" with "maternal uncle", and the pronouns "he" and "his" with "she" and "her".

## Step 3: Rewrite the text with the swapped gender-specific references.
A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum for the past 10 days. During this time, she had three episodes of blood in her urine. Six years ago, she was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis after a positive routine tuberculin skin test, and she was treated accordingly. Her maternal uncle has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient does not take any medications.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing progressive shortness of breath and an intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum for the past 10 days.
Do you have any recent history of urinary tract infections or noticed any changes in your urine?
Yes, I've had three episodes of blood in my urine recently.
Do you have any history of kidney disease, or has anyone in your family suffered from kidney issues?
No direct history of kidney disease, but my maternal uncle has systemic lupus erythematosus.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 24-year-old woman.
Have you experienced any joint pain or skin rashes recently?
No, I have not experienced any joint pain or skin rashes.
Have you been diagnosed with any autoimmune diseases or are you currently on any medications?
I was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis six years ago and treated for it, but I am not currently taking any medications and have not been diagnosed with any autoimmune diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Goodpasture syndrome.
